awd_titl_txt: Cosmological and Astrophysical Signatures of Axions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Andrew Long at Rice University.  

Over 40 years ago a hypothetical elementary particle known as the axion was proposed to explain a perplexing property of the neutron.  For the following decades experimental campaigns have been underway to try to detect axions and axion-like particles in the laboratory.  Through his work Professor Long aims to make robust predictions for several cosmological and astrophysical signatures of axions.  These theoretical predictions will motivate future observations and facilitate the interpretation of data, with the goal of making possible the discovery of the axion.  These efforts advance the national interest by promoting the progress of fundamental science, since the discovery of an axion would have deep and far-reaching implications for our understanding of the laws of nature and the composition of the Universe.   In addition to its central science objectives, this project will have substantial broader impacts.  At least one graduate student researcher will assist Professor Long’s research, thereby providing an opportunity for essential training of early-career physicists.  In addition, Professor Long will deliver lectures at local high schools and invite students to visit the campus of his university in order to encourage the next generation of scientists.  

More technically, this research program is divided into three objectives. First, Professor Long's research group will study how axion strings may leave a subtle imprint on the polarization of the cosmic microwave background radiation. They will calculate the appropriate two-point correlation function using a combination of analytical and numerical methods, and by comparing these predictions with the existing data and the projected sensitivities of next-generation surveys, they will evaluate the efficacy of these cosmological measurements to probe axion strings. Second, they will study the electromagnetic radiation produced when an axion star transits the strong magnetic field environment of a neutron star. They will model this system with a numerical lattice simulation, calculate the resultant radiation spectrum, both directly from the simulation as well as using a dipole approximation, and assess the prospects for detecting this radiation with radio observations.  As the third and final objective, the PI’s group will study the emission of axion particles from stars including our own Sun. By focusing on a previously-unstudied interaction between the axion particles and ordinary matter, the group will calculate the flux of axions produced by these stars, evaluate the effect that this radiation has on the temperature of the star, and assess the implications for recent anomalies related to stellar axion emission.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded the research activities of Professor Andrew Long (PI) and several graduate students at Rice University from September 2021 through August 2024.  

Over 40 years ago, a hypothetical elementary particle known as the axion was proposed to explain a perplexing property of the neutron.  Simultaneously, researchers recognized that axion-like particles with properties similar to axions are generic predictions of theories of fundamental physics, including string theory.  For the following decades, experimental campaigns have been underway to try and detect axions and axion-like particles in the laboratory.  These efforts advance the national interest by promoting the progress of fundamental science: the discovery of an axion would have deep and far-reaching implications for our understanding of the laws of nature and the composition of the Universe. 

Through the research supported by this award, PI Long and his team worked to develop robust theoretical predictions for several cosmological and astrophysical signatures of axions.  While observations of cosmological and astrophysics systems do not allow for the same level of control as an experiment in a laboratory, the wealth of precision data available from these measurements makes them powerful probes of hypothetical new physics, such as axions.  Theoretical investigation and exploration of this kind are an essential element of the scientific enterprise, since they often point to new directions for observation, experimentation, and discovery.  The key outcomes and intellectual merit of this project are summarized below.  

PI Long studied bounded collections of axions as well as another hypothetical particle called a dark photon, which is a higher-spin “cousin” of the axion.  Both particles are expected to form cloud-like configurations distributed across the cosmos.  These axion and dark photon “stars” are predicted to emit electromagnetic radiation.  PI Long calculated the properties of this light (e.g., energy spectrum), in order to derive its distinctive signatures (e.g., polarization pattern), and thereby inform searches for these objects using arrays of telescopes.  This work revealed that measurements of the polarization pattern of the emission could be used to distinguish axion stars from dark photon stars, and ascertain the polarization state of the dark photon star.  

PI Long studied axions in the extreme environment of compact stars.  Axions are expected to be emitted from the interior of these hot and dense stars.  This affords two channels for the detection of axions: by observing the indirect effect that the axion emission has on its host star, and by observing the emitted axion particles directly.  PI Long’s team, including two graduate students at Rice University, was the first to systematically calculate axion emission via an exotic interaction.  Among astrophysical systems, this interaction is only relevant in neutron stars (and supernovae), thanks to their abundance of muons.  This work represents a first step toward discovering the axion’s exotic interactions with ordinary particles through future observations of neutron stars and supernovae.  In other work, PI Long’s team systematically studied the spontaneous conversion of axions into photons in a neutron star’s magnetosphere, discovering a new channel for this conversion to be resonantly enhanced.  If precision observations of neutron star spectra reveal the predicted spectra features, it would open a new avenue for the discovery of these elusive hypothetical particles.  

PI Long studied the imprint of axion-like particles on the polarization pattern of the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMBR).  Previous work had identified that under certain conditions, axion-like particles could form spatially-extended objects known as axion strings, which may zig-zag across the observable universe.  In a series of research projects, PI Long and a graduate student at Rice University (and other collaborators) worked to characterize the imprint of this hypothetical axion string network on the CMBR polarization.  Using publicly available data from several CMBR telescopes, they identified that the data was compatible with the absence of axion strings, and they placed a strong constraints on the properties and abundance of these objects.  They extrapolated that measurements with next-generation telescopes would be precise enough to either detect or “rule out” axion strings in our Universe today.  To facilitate that experimental program, they worked to characterize the non-Gaussian nature of the signal, and they employed machine learning techniques (spherical convolutional neural network) to develop the tools that will be needed to extract the subtle signal from future data sets.  

The PI's project has had several broader impacts.  The training and professional development of three graduate students, who collaborated with the PI at Rice University, allowed them to earn Ph.D. degrees and progress onto work as professional researchers.  During the award period, the PI delivered numerous public lectures about his work and astrophysics more broadly.  The audiences varied, but perhaps the most impactful experiences were delivering summer school lectures to high-school students in Houston.  Several of them are now pursuing STEM degrees at colleges and universities around the country (including Rice University!).
